Description: Coarse ware pottery jar with two handles; hard pinkish clay with abundant gritty inclusions; very few traces of thick matt red slip; chips in rim; inside is a lump of hardened gum; vessel is wheel-made but very uneven.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Tell Dafana, "Qasr", east annex (C), chamber 3.
Curator's comments: Certainly the pot “filled with resin [...] found in chamber 3" mentioned by in W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 65 § 61 and 75 § 72, pl. xxxv, 55. It is similar to London, BM, EA 23650, which is certainly "the pot 55 [...] rather common in chamber 18" (ibid.). See also Liverpool, WM, 47.56.11 (ex-Edinburgh NMS, A.1887.93, given to Liverpool in 1947) said to come "from a chamber in the Palace Fort". The lump of resin it contains was analysed in 1889 and found to be Chian turpentine: E.M. Holmes, "Note on two resins used by the Ancient Egyptians", The Pharmaceutical Journal and Transactions, November 17, 1889, pp. 387-389.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 64, 65, 66 § 61, pl. xxxv, 55)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.94, p.107, p.137-139, p.194, pl.36, p.218, pl.60)
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: 1888,0204.140 (incorrect number given on p.218 of Leclère and Spencer 2014)
